meta.source: Generated by AI Assistant (current, CompTIA A+ focus)

fragen.frage: An HDD (Hard Disk Drive) uses flash memory to store data, similar to an SSD.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An HDD stores data on rotating magnetic platters that are mechanically written to and read from. An SSD (Solid State Drive) uses flash memory chips and has no moving parts.

fragen.frage: When troubleshooting a PC, you should first check the most complex components, as they are the most common source of problems.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A best practice is to first check the simplest and most obvious things (e.g., power supply, cable connections, reboot) before moving on to more complex steps. This often saves time and effort.

fragen.frage: The Windows operating system uses the ext4 file system by default for its system partition.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Windows operating systems primarily use NTFS (New Technology File System) or older FAT variants. ext4 is the default file system for many Linux distributions.

fragen.frage: A Category 5e (Cat 5e) Ethernet patch cable is suitable for Gigabit Ethernet (1000Base-T).
fragen.erklaerung: True! Cat 5e is the minimum standard for Gigabit Ethernet. For higher speeds (e.g., 10 Gigabit Ethernet), Cat 6, Cat 6a, or higher are required.

fragen.frage: The 'Airplane Mode' on a smartphone only disables the cellular connection, leaving Wi-Fi and Bluetooth active.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Airplane mode disables all wireless communication modules: cellular, Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, and GPS. You can manually re-enable Wi-Fi or Bluetooth, but they are off by default.

fragen.frage: A strong password should be at least 8 characters long and contain a combination of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Length is often more important than complexity. Recommendations today often lean towards passphrases or passwords with 12+ characters.

fragen.frage: In virtualization, a hypervisor allows guest operating systems to directly use the hardware without any abstraction layer.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A hypervisor is the software that virtualizes the hardware and creates an abstraction layer. Guest systems receive a virtualized version of the hardware, not direct access. This allows multiple VMs to run simultaneously.

fragen.frage: A typical RAM type for modern desktop PCs is DDR3 SDRAM.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DDR3 is an older RAM generation. For modern desktop PCs, DDR4 or DDR5 SDRAM is the standard.

fragen.frage: When troubleshooting, you should always test hypotheses on the most complex and expensive components first.
fragen.erklaerung: False — You should start with the simplest and cheapest solutions that cause the least disruption, and only then move on to more complex steps.

fragen.frage: The Task Manager in Windows can be used to monitor CPU usage, memory, and running processes.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Task Manager (Ctrl+Shift+Esc) is an important tool for system administrators and support technicians to diagnose performance issues.

fragen.frage: The IP address 169.254.x.x (APIPA) is assigned by a DHCP server when it is overloaded.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An APIPA (Automatic Private IP Addressing) address is automatically assigned by a Windows client when no DHCP server is reachable, not when it's overloaded. It allows communication on the local network segment.

fragen.frage: Smartphones and tablets typically use UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) as their firmware interface.
fragen.erklaerung: False — UEFI is primarily used in PCs and servers. Mobile devices typically use custom bootloader software specific to their ARM architecture and operating systems (Android, iOS).

fragen.frage: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) is used exclusively to speed up a user's internet access.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The main purpose of a VPN is to create a secure and encrypted connection over an insecure network, often to provide remote users with secure access to a corporate network. Speed improvement is rare and more of a side effect.

fragen.frage: RAM is a non-volatile memory that retains its data even without power.
fragen.erklaerung: False — RAM (Random Access Memory) is a volatile memory, meaning it loses its data as soon as the power is cut. ROM (Read-Only Memory) or flash memory (SSD) are non-volatile memories.

fragen.frage: In troubleshooting, 'verifying the solution' should be the first step.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first step in the troubleshooting process is to 'identify the problem'. Verifying the solution comes only after a potential solution has been implemented.

fragen.frage: A 64-bit operating system can run both 32-bit and 64-bit applications.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is made possible by compatibility layers, which facilitated the transition from 32-bit to 64-bit architectures.

fragen.frage: The 'ipconfig /all' command in Windows displays all network adapters, but no DHCP server information.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'ipconfig /all' displays detailed information about all network adapters, including the DHCP server address (if an IP address was obtained via DHCP).

fragen.frage: A smartphone with the Android operating system cannot install apps from third-party sources (outside the official store).
fragen.erklaerung: False — Android allows the installation of apps from 'unknown sources' (sideloading) if the user enables this in the security settings. This is a potential security risk.

fragen.frage: Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) is the most secure authentication method available.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 2FA is very secure, but Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) with more than two independent factors (e.g., knowledge, possession, AND inherence) is even more secure, although less common in practice.

fragen.frage: The CPU (Central Processing Unit) is primarily responsible for storing data.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The CPU is the 'brain' of the computer and is responsible for executing commands and calculations. Data storage is handled by components like RAM, HDD, or SSD.

fragen.frage: It is a good practice not to document the cause of recurring problems to save time.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Detailed documentation of problems, causes, and solutions is crucial to speed up future troubleshooting and prevent recurring problems. This saves time in the long run.

fragen.frage: Windows Safe Mode starts the operating system with a minimal set of drivers and services.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is useful for diagnosing and fixing problems caused by faulty drivers, software, or malware, as many components are not loaded in safe mode.

fragen.frage: A subnet with the mask 255.255.255.240 (/28) provides space for 14 usable host addresses.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A /28 network has 4 host bits (32-28=4), which results in 2^4 = 16 total addresses. Subtracting the network and broadcast addresses leaves 14 usable host addresses.

fragen.frage: Apple's iOS operating system allows the installation of apps from any source (sideloading) by default.
fragen.erklaerung: False — iOS is a closed system that primarily allows apps only from the official App Store to ensure security. Sideloading is highly restricted without a jailbreak.

fragen.frage: Phishing attacks always aim to steal victims' credit card data.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Phishing attacks can have a variety of goals, including login credentials, bank details, personal information, or even installing malware. Credit card data is just one possible target.

fragen.frage: A power supply unit (PSU) converts alternating current (AC) from the wall outlet to direct current (DC) for the computer components.
fragen.erklaerung: True! It supplies the necessary voltages (e.g., +12V, +5V, +3.3V) for the CPU, motherboard, graphics cards, and other components.

fragen.frage: The first step in CompTIA's 6-step troubleshooting process is 'implementing the solution'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first step is to 'identify the problem'. Implementing the solution comes later in the process.

fragen.frage: The Linux file system is a hierarchical structure that starts with the root directory '/'.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a fundamental concept of Unix-like operating systems, where all directories and files are arranged under the root directory.

fragen.frage: A router operates on Layer 2 (Data Link Layer) of the OSI model.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A router operates on Layer 3 (Network Layer) and is responsible for routing IP packets between different networks. Switches operate on Layer 2.

fragen.frage: The PIN lock on a smartphone completely protects the data on the device from any unauthorized access.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A PIN lock provides basic protection against casual thieves. However, experienced attackers could access the data by removing the storage medium or exploiting software vulnerabilities.

fragen.frage: Malware that disguises itself as legitimate software to entice users to download and install it is called a rootkit.
fragen.erklaerung: False — This description fits a Trojan horse. A rootkit attempts to hide its presence on a compromised system by manipulating system functions.

fragen.frage: A CPU socket of type LGA (Land Grid Array) has pins on the processor itself.
fragen.erklaerung: False — On LGA sockets, the pins are on the motherboard and the processor has contact pads. On PGA (Pin Grid Array) sockets, the pins are on the processor.

fragen.frage: For intermittent problems, it is best to pause troubleshooting and only address the problem again when it becomes a permanent failure.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Intermittent problems are often harder to diagnose, but it is important to gather as much information as possible while the problem is occurring. One should keep logs and try to identify patterns, even if it is not permanent.

fragen.frage: The 'chkdsk' utility in Windows is used to check and repair bad sectors on a hard disk.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'chkdsk' (Check Disk) is an important tool for checking file system integrity and fixing logical and sometimes even physical errors on disks.

fragen.frage: A switch is a device that forwards data packets between different networks based on IP addresses.
fragen.erklaerung: False — This describes the function of a router. A switch forwards frames within a local area network (LAN) based on MAC addresses.

fragen.frage: The tethering feature of a smartphone allows sharing the smartphone's mobile data connection with other devices.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This can be done via Wi-Fi (hotspot), Bluetooth, or USB and is useful for providing internet to laptops or tablets on the go.

fragen.frage: Malware that embeds itself in other programs or documents and replicates is called a worm.
fragen.erklaerung: False — This description fits a computer virus. A worm self-replicates and spreads over networks without needing a host file.

fragen.frage: An optical drive can read and write CDs, DVDs, and Blu-ray Discs, regardless of the type of drive.
fragen.erklaerung: False — There are different types of optical drives (CD-ROM, DVD-ROM, Blu-ray drive) and not every drive can read or write all media types. A Blu-ray drive is backward compatible, but a CD drive cannot read Blu-rays.

fragen.frage: The first step of the CompTIA troubleshooting process is 'documenting the problem'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first step is to 'identify the problem'. Documentation should occur throughout the process, but it is not the first step.

fragen.frage: The Windows Registry is a central hierarchical database that stores configuration data for the operating system and installed applications.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Editing the registry (e.g., with `regedit`) should be done with great care, as errors can lead to system instability.

fragen.frage: The `ping` command tests connectivity to another host on the network by sending UDP packets.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'ping' uses the ICMP protocol (Internet Control Message Protocol), not UDP, to send echo requests and replies.

fragen.frage: GPS (Global Positioning System) on mobile devices always requires an active internet connection to function.
fragen.erklaerung: False — GPS receives signals from satellites and does not require an internet connection for positioning. However, an internet connection may be helpful for displaying map data or for A-GPS (Assisted GPS).

fragen.frage: A Denial-of-Service (DoS) attack aims to steal confidential data from a server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A DoS attack aims to disrupt or prevent the availability of a service or system. Stealing data is the goal of a data theft attack.

fragen.frage: A Solid State Drive (SSD) is generally more susceptible to data loss from magnetic fields than an HDD.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SSDs store data in flash memory, which is not magnetic and thus immune to data loss from magnetic fields. HDDs store data magnetically and are therefore susceptible.

fragen.frage: It is always the best strategy to test the most commonly used solutions for a problem first, even if they are complex.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The best strategy is often to try the simplest and least invasive solutions first. Complexity and frequency of use are not always the best indicators for the starting point of troubleshooting.

fragen.frage: The 'format c:' command in Windows deletes all data on the C partition and prepares it for a new installation.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This command is very powerful and should be used with extreme caution as it can cause irreversible data loss.

fragen.frage: A WLAN Access Point (AP) is typically used to connect wired devices wirelessly.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A WLAN AP is used to connect *wireless* devices to a *wired* network or to network multiple wireless devices in a BSS (Basic Service Set).

fragen.frage: A 'Hard Reset' of a mobile device deletes all personal data and resets the device to factory settings.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is often a last resort for persistent software problems or before selling a device. You should always make a backup beforehand.

fragen.frage: Social engineering is a technique that aims to exploit technical vulnerabilities in systems.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Social engineering manipulates people to reveal information or perform actions. It is not about technical vulnerabilities, but about the human component of security.

fragen.frage: The power supply of a PCIe graphics card is always provided by the motherboard slot alone.
fragen.erklaerung: False — High-performance PCIe graphics cards often require additional power connectors (6-pin or 8-pin) directly from the power supply, as the PCIe slot alone cannot provide enough power.

fragen.frage: The seventh step of the CompTIA troubleshooting process is 'verifying the solution'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The CompTIA method has 6 steps. The fourth step is 'verifying the solution'.

fragen.frage: On macOS, applications can only be installed through the App Store to ensure system security.
fragen.erklaerung: False — On macOS, applications can also be downloaded and installed from other sources. However, they must be allowed in the security settings ('Gatekeeper') (e.g., from identified developers).

fragen.frage: A DHCP server assigns IP addresses statically, i.e., the address never changes.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A DHCP server assigns IP addresses dynamically, usually for a certain period of time (lease time). Static IP addresses are configured manually or assigned by DHCP servers as 'reservations' based on the MAC address.

fragen.frage: The NFC (Near Field Communication) standard in smartphones enables wireless payments and data transfer over short distances.
fragen.erklaerung: True! NFC is used for applications such as contactless payments, fast pairing of Bluetooth devices, or reading tags. The range is only a few centimeters.

fragen.frage: A keylogger is a hardware component used exclusively for monitoring network traffic.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A keylogger can be either software or hardware that records keystrokes. It is not used for monitoring network traffic, but for capturing user input.

fragen.frage: A fuser in a laser printer is responsible for permanently fixing the toner to the paper.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is done through heat and pressure, causing the toner to melt and fuse with the paper fibers. If the fuser is defective, the toner can simply be wiped off.

fragen.frage: Once a problem has been resolved, the troubleshooting process should be terminated without any further steps.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The CompTIA method states that after verifying the solution, one should take further steps, such as implementing preventive measures and documenting the problem and solution.

fragen.frage: The 'sudo' command in Linux allows a normal user to execute commands with root privileges.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'sudo' (superuser do) is a crucial tool for system administration as it allows for elevated permission control without having to log in directly as root.

fragen.frage: An unmanaged switch is ideal for complex network configurations as it offers many options for traffic control.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An unmanaged switch is a plug-and-play device with no configuration options. For complex networks with VLANs, QoS, or port security, a managed switch is required.

fragen.frage: Factory resetting mobile devices always deletes all data permanently and irretrievably.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A simple factory reset makes data inaccessible, but it can be recovered with special tools. For secure deletion, encryption and/or special wiping software should be used, especially before selling.

fragen.frage: Protection against ransomware is solely the responsibility of an antivirus program.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Protection against ransomware requires a multi-layered approach: antivirus, firewalls, regular backups, user awareness training, patch management, and Endpoint Detection and Response (EDR) solutions.

fragen.frage: A motherboard with a Z-series chipset is typically designed for office PCs without overclocking options.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Z-series chipsets (e.g., Z690) are high-end chipsets from Intel, specifically designed for performance users and overclocking. Chipsets like the H- or B-series are more suitable for office PCs.

fragen.frage: The `ping` command is primarily for measuring the bandwidth between two network devices.
fragen.erklaerung: False — `ping` measures the reachability and latency (delay) to a host. For bandwidth measurement, other tools like `iperf` or `speedtest` are more suitable.

fragen.frage: A Solid State Drive (SSD) is generally faster than an HDD because it has no moving parts.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The higher speed of SSDs (especially in random reads/writes) is due to the flash memory technology, which drastically reduces access times compared to mechanical hard drives.

fragen.frage: The `netsh wlan show profiles` command in Windows only shows the SSID of the saved Wi-Fi profiles, but not the passwords.
fragen.erklaerung: False — With the command 'netsh wlan show profile name=PROFILE_NAME key=clear', you can display the password (Key Content) of a saved Wi-Fi profile in clear text.

fragen.frage: Screen mirroring from mobile devices is always a secure method of presentation because the data is sent directly to the display device.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Wireless screen mirroring (e.g., via Miracast, Chromecast) can pose security risks depending on the implementation if the connection is not sufficiently encrypted. Confidential content could be intercepted.

fragen.frage: A DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) is a network area that hosts publicly accessible servers and serves as a buffer between the internal network and the Internet.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) increases security by preventing direct attacks on internal servers and still protecting the internal network if the DMZ is compromised.

fragen.frage: A Power Supply Unit (PSU) fan that is not spinning is always a sign of a hardware defect in the power supply.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Many modern power supplies have a 'Zero RPM' or 'Fanless Mode' feature where the fan does not spin at low load or low temperature to be quieter. This is not a defect.

fragen.frage: When a user reports a problem, the first step is to immediately implement a solution.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first step is to question the user to identify the problem and gather as much information as possible. A hasty implementation of a solution without understanding the problem can cause new problems.

fragen.frage: The 'msconfig' command in Windows is a utility for managing device states and drivers.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'msconfig' (System Configuration) is a utility for managing startup options, services, and system startup items. The Device Manager ('devmgmt.msc') is for devices and drivers.

fragen.frage: A mesh network uses multiple access points to provide a single, extensive Wi-Fi signal.
fragen.erklaerung: True! In a mesh network, the access points can communicate wirelessly with each other to extend the range and coverage and provide better redundancy than traditional Wi-Fi systems with extenders.

fragen.frage: A QR code is a one-dimensional barcode mainly used for product information.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A QR code (Quick Response Code) is a two-dimensional barcode that can store a larger amount of information than one-dimensional barcodes. It is often used for URLs, Wi-Fi access data, or contact details.

fragen.frage: BIOS passwords on PCs are primarily intended to protect the operating system from malware.
fragen.erklaerung: False — BIOS passwords (setup password, user password) are intended to control access to BIOS settings or system startup to prevent unauthorized hardware or boot changes. They do not directly protect the operating system from malware.

fragen.frage: A fan with a 4-pin connector can control its speed via PWM (Pulse Width Modulation).
fragen.erklaerung: True! The fourth pin is for PWM control, which allows for precise and efficient control of the fan speed, resulting in quieter operation and better cooling. 3-pin fans are controlled by voltage.

fragen.frage: 'Verifying the solution' in the troubleshooting process means only briefly checking if the problem has temporarily disappeared.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Verification should be thorough and confirm that the problem is permanently fixed and that no new problems have arisen. This also includes testing under different conditions or after a reboot.

fragen.frage: The 'gpupdate /force' command in Windows forces the application of all Group Policy settings on the local computer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a useful command to apply Group Policy changes immediately without waiting for the next automatic refresh cycle or rebooting the computer.

fragen.frage: The ARP (Address Resolution Protocol) protocol resolves IP addresses to domain names.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ARP resolves IP addresses to MAC addresses. DNS (Domain Name System) is responsible for resolving domain names to IP addresses.

fragen.frage: Rooting an Android smartphone increases its security through deeper access to the system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Rooting (or jailbreaking on iOS) grants the user root access to the operating system, which potentially reduces security. While it can offer more control, it can also make the device more vulnerable to malware and misconfigurations.

fragen.frage: Malware that spreads by exploiting zero-day vulnerabilities is particularly difficult to detect and combat.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Zero-day vulnerabilities are not yet known to the software manufacturer, so there are no patches. Attackers can use them effectively until the vulnerability is discovered and fixed.

fragen.frage: A motherboard with an integrated graphics card always offers the same performance as a dedicated graphics card.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Integrated graphics solutions usually share the system's main memory and are designed for simple tasks. Dedicated graphics cards have their own, fast memory and offer significantly higher performance for demanding applications and games.

fragen.frage: The `ipconfig /release` command in Windows permanently deletes the IP address of a network adapter.
fragen.erklaerung: False — `ipconfig /release` releases the current IP address (from the DHCP server). The address is not permanently deleted, but is made available again to the DHCP server. A new address can be requested with `ipconfig /renew`.

fragen.frage: The 'bootloop' problem on a smartphone only occurs when the battery is defective.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A bootloop (device restarts repeatedly) can have many causes, including software errors (after updates), faulty apps, corrupted system files, or even hardware problems, not just a defective battery.

fragen.frage: A secure Wi-Fi network should use at least WEP encryption.
fragen.erklaerung: False — WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy) is extremely insecure and should no longer be used. Modern Wi-Fi networks should use at least WPA2 or, better, WPA3 encryption.

fragen.frage: The main task of a Northbridge chipset on a motherboard is to manage I/O peripherals (e.g., USB, SATA).
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Northbridge (if present, often integrated into the CPU) manages the fast communication between the CPU, RAM, and the graphics card (PCIe). The Southbridge (or PCH) is responsible for I/O peripherals.

fragen.frage: A 'Bluescreen of Death' (BSOD) in Windows is always an indication of a hardware defect.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A BSOD can have many causes, including faulty drivers, software conflicts, system file corruption, or even malware, not exclusively hardware defects. A more detailed analysis of the error code is necessary.

fragen.frage: The 'ping -t' command in Windows continuously sends ping requests until it is manually stopped.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is useful for monitoring a permanent connection to a host and detecting intermittent network problems.

fragen.frage: The eSIM technology in mobile devices requires a physical SIM card to be inserted into the device.
fragen.erklaerung: False — eSIM (embedded SIM) is a programmable SIM card permanently built into the device. It makes physical SIM cards obsolete and allows easy switching of mobile carriers via software.

fragen.frage: Biometric data (e.g., fingerprints) should be stored in clear text to allow for fast authentication.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Biometric data should never be stored in clear text. Instead, hashes or templates of the biometric features are stored, which are compared during authentication. This protects privacy in case of a data breach.

fragen.frage: A Front Panel Connector on a motherboard is responsible for supplying power to the CPU.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Front Panel Connectors connect the buttons (Power, Reset) and LEDs (Power, HDD activity) from the case to the motherboard. The CPU power is supplied via special ATX12V connectors directly from the power supply.

fragen.frage: When troubleshooting, one should not use external resources (internet, manuals) to improve one's own skills.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Using external resources is an important and often necessary step in the troubleshooting process. Forums, manufacturer documentation, and online databases can provide valuable clues for problem solving.

fragen.frage: A 'Clean Install' of an operating system deletes all data on the hard drive and reinstalls the OS.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is often the last resort for persistent system problems and provides a 'fresh' system without legacy issues. A backup of the data is essential beforehand.

fragen.frage: The DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) protocol is responsible for the secure encryption of network traffic.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DHCP is responsible for the dynamic assignment of IP addresses and other network configuration parameters. Protocols like TLS/SSL or IPsec are responsible for encryption.

fragen.frage: A 'jailbroken' iPhone is more secure than a non-jailbroken iPhone.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A jailbroken iPhone has had the security restrictions imposed by Apple removed, which, while offering more freedom, also makes the device more vulnerable to malware and security risks by bypassing sandbox mechanisms.

fragen.frage: Using standard ports (e.g., port 22 for SSH) for services is a proven security practice because they are easy to remember.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Although standard ports are well-known, changing standard ports (port knocking or port obfuscation) is a simple method to reduce the attack surface ('Security through Obscurity'). However, it does not replace real security.

fragen.frage: The Thunderbolt interface only supports data transfer, not video output.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Thunderbolt (e.g., Thunderbolt 3/4) is a versatile interface that supports both high-speed data transfer (PCIe) and video output (DisplayPort) over a single port. Often realized via a USB-C connector.

fragen.frage: The `sfc /scannow` command in Windows checks the integrity of all protected system files and replaces damaged or missing files.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'sfc' (System File Checker) is a useful tool for fixing problems caused by corrupt or manipulated system files and can often resolve system instability.

fragen.frage: The subnet mask 255.255.0.0 (/16) can be assigned to a host on the 192.168.1.0 network.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The 192.168.1.0 network is a Class C network. A /16 mask would result in a larger network range that does not match the host IP address. A /24 mask (255.255.255.0) would be appropriate for 192.168.1.0.

fragen.frage: A hotspot on a mobile device allows sharing the device's internet connection with other devices.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a common method to connect laptops, tablets, or other smartphones to a device's mobile data connection.

fragen.frage: Secure password management involves storing all passwords in a simple text file on the desktop.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Passwords should never be stored unencrypted. Instead, password managers should be used, which store passwords encrypted and can often generate secure passwords.

fragen.frage: The ATX (Advanced Technology eXtended) form factor is the smallest and most compact standard for motherboards.
fragen.erklaerung: False — ATX is a widely used, but not the smallest, form factor. Micro-ATX (mATX) and Mini-ITX are smaller standards for more compact builds.

fragen.frage: After implementing a solution in troubleshooting, there is no need to contact the customer again.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An important step is follow-up communication with the customer to ensure that the problem is permanently resolved and the customer is satisfied with the solution. This is part of the documentation and learning process.

fragen.frage: The 'chmod 777 file.txt' command in Linux grants the owner, group, and others full read, write, and execute permissions for the file.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a very open permission that should generally be avoided for security reasons unless absolutely necessary.

fragen.frage: An Access Point (AP) in a Wi-Fi network sends and receives radio signals from wireless devices.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The AP is the central component of a Wi-Fi network that allows wireless clients to access the wired network.

fragen.frage: An NFC (Near Field Communication) tag on a mobile device can only read data, but not write it.
fragen.erklaerung: False — NFC tags can be both read and written, depending on the type of tag and the permissions of the writing device. Many NFC tags are read-only after being written.

fragen.frage: The principle of least privilege is a security measure that states that users and processes should only be granted the minimum necessary permissions.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This minimizes the risk that a compromised account or application can cause excessive damage and is a fundamental security concept.

fragen.frage: A DisplayPort connection cannot transmit audio signals, only video signals.
fragen.erklaerung: False — DisplayPort can transmit both high-resolution video signals and audio signals. This makes it a versatile interface for monitors and other display devices.

fragen.frage: The 6 steps of the CompTIA troubleshooting process are: Identify the problem, establish a theory of probable cause, test the theory, establish a plan of action and implement the solution, verify full system functionality and implement preventive measures, and document findings, actions, and outcomes.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is the correct and complete sequence of steps taught in the CompTIA A+ certification to systematically solve problems.

fragen.frage: A 'rollback' in software development means installing a new version of an application.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A rollback means reverting a previously installed (often faulty) version of an application or system to a previous, working version. It is the opposite of a new installation or an upgrade.

fragen.frage: The loopback address 127.0.0.1 is used to communicate with a remote server on the Internet.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The loopback address (localhost) is used to communicate with the local computer itself. It never leaves the device and is not intended for communication with remote servers.

fragen.frage: 'Hot swapping' a component is only possible when the device is turned off.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Hot swapping (or hot plugging) refers to connecting or disconnecting components (e.g., hard drives, USB devices) *while the device is running*, without turning it off. This is possible with some components (e.g., SATA hard drives, USB).

fragen.frage: A smartphone with a broken screen is a case for software troubleshooting.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A broken screen is a hardware problem and requires a screen replacement, not software troubleshooting.

fragen.frage: A malware scan on an infected system should always be performed in normal Windows mode to capture all system processes.
fragen.erklaerung: False — In case of a malware infection, it is often better to run the scan in safe mode or from an external boot medium. In normal mode, the malware could be active and hide from the scanner or even prevent its removal.

fragen.frage: The maximum range for a single Bluetooth connection is typically up to 100 meters (Class 1).
fragen.erklaerung: True! Although many consumer devices are Class 2 (up to 10 meters), there are also Class 1 devices that can reach this range. The range depends on the Bluetooth class and environmental conditions.

fragen.frage: A 'Ghost Image' is a backup of the operating system and all installed programs that can be used for quick recovery.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is an efficient method to quickly restore systems or configure multiple identical systems, as the image is an exact copy of the entire system.

fragen.frage: The SSID (Service Set Identifier) of a Wi-Fi network should always be hidden (SSID broadcast disabled) to increase security.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Hiding the SSID is a measure of 'Security through Obscurity'. It does not significantly hinder attackers from detecting it, but can limit usability. The primary security measures should be strong passwords and WPA2/WPA3 encryption.

fragen.frage: A 'Soft Reset' of a mobile device is equivalent to restarting the device and does not delete any data.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A soft reset (e.g., long-pressing the power button until the device restarts) is a simple method to fix minor software problems or when the device is unresponsive, without losing data.

fragen.frage: A smart home hub is a device that enables central control and automation of smart home devices.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Smart home hubs often support various communication protocols (e.g., Zigbee, Z-Wave, Wi-Fi) to integrate a variety of devices and create scenarios.

fragen.frage: A system with a defective GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) always displays a 'Bluescreen of Death'.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A defective GPU can cause image artifacts, no image, system crashes, or freezing. A BSOD can be a consequence, but can also have many other causes and is not an exclusive symptom of a defective GPU.

fragen.frage: The `DISM.exe /Online /Cleanup-Image /RestoreHealth` command in Windows can repair corrupt Windows system files.
fragen.erklaerung: True! DISM (Deployment Image Servicing and Management) is a powerful command-line tool for maintaining and repairing Windows images. It can fix problems that SFC could not resolve.

fragen.frage: The Windows Firewall is a hardware component that filters network traffic.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The Windows Firewall is a software firewall integrated into the operating system. Hardware firewalls are separate devices that filter network traffic at the network perimeter.

fragen.frage: Configuring a static IP address on a Windows PC is the preferred method in large networks.
fragen.erklaerung: False — In large networks, dynamic IP address assignment via DHCP is the preferred method to simplify administration and avoid IP address conflicts. Static IPs are more suitable for servers or network devices.

fragen.frage: A 'kiosk mode' on a mobile device restricts the use of the device to one or a few specific applications.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is useful for use cases such as point-of-sale systems, information kiosks, or devices issued to customers or employees with restricted privileges.

fragen.frage: A processor with the designation 'Ryzen 7' is typically from Intel.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'Ryzen' is the brand name for CPUs from the manufacturer AMD. 'Core i7' or 'Xeon' would be designations from Intel.

fragen.frage: Establishing a theory of probable cause' is the last step in the CompTIA troubleshooting process.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'Establishing a theory of probable cause' is the second step. The last step is 'Document findings, actions, and outcomes'.

fragen.frage: The 'sudo apt update' command in Linux is the only way to install software on a Debian-based system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — `sudo apt update` only updates the package lists. To install software, `sudo apt install PACKAGE_NAME` is used. You can also install software via package files (`.deb`) with `dpkg -i`.

fragen.frage: A cable tester for Ethernet cables can detect faulty wiring (e.g., split pair).
fragen.erklaerung: True! Simple cable testers only check for continuity, but more advanced testers can also detect more complex errors such as split pairs or attenuation problems.

fragen.frage: A wireless headset that does not connect to a smartphone is always a hardware defect.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Connection problems can have many causes: empty batteries, incorrect pairing modes, software problems (drivers, updates), interference, or even a simple restart of the device can help. A hardware defect is only one possibility.

fragen.frage: A firewall protects a network by only allowing known, secure applications and blocking the rest (whitelisting).
fragen.erklaerung: False — A firewall can operate in either whitelisting mode (explicitly allowed is allowed, everything else is forbidden) or blacklisting mode (explicitly forbidden is forbidden, everything else is allowed). Whitelisting is more secure, but also more complex to configure.

fragen.frage: A processor with an integrated heat spreader is designed to transfer heat directly to the motherboard cooler.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The integrated heat spreader (IHS) is designed to distribute heat from the CPU dies evenly over a larger area so that the attached *CPU cooler* (not the motherboard cooler) can dissipate the heat efficiently.

fragen.frage: After implementing a solution, it is sufficient to mark the problem as 'resolved' for the time being and take no further preventive steps.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The penultimate step in the CompTIA troubleshooting process is to 'take preventive measures' to prevent the problem from recurring. Only then is everything documented.

fragen.frage: The 'fsck' command in Linux is used to check and repair file system integrity.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'fsck' (File System Consistency Check) is the Linux equivalent of Windows 'chkdsk' and is an indispensable tool for recovering from file system errors.

fragen.frage: A hub is an intelligent network device that sends data traffic to the recipient in a targeted manner.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A hub is a 'dumb' device that simply forwards data to all connected devices. It operates on Layer 1 of the OSI model. A switch, on the other hand, is intelligent and sends data to the correct recipient in a targeted manner (Layer 2).

fragen.frage: The 'Fast Charging' standard for mobile devices is a universal standard that is implemented in the same way by all manufacturers.
fragen.erklaerung: False — There are several competing fast charging standards (e.g., Qualcomm Quick Charge, USB Power Delivery, OnePlus Warp Charge) that use different technologies and are not always compatible with each other.

fragen.frage: A hardware token for two-factor authentication (2FA) is vulnerable to phishing attacks.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A hardware token (e.g., FIDO U2F) is generally very resistant to phishing because it verifies the origin of the login request and sends the code only to the real website. Software tokens (OTP via app) are more vulnerable.

fragen.frage: A UEFI (Unified Extensible Firmware Interface) is the successor to BIOS and offers a graphical interface as well as support for larger hard drives.
fragen.erklaerung: True! UEFI offers many advantages over legacy BIOS, including Secure Boot, faster boot times, and support for GPT partition tables (larger than 2TB).

fragen.frage: If a computer does not start, the first thing to do is to replace the hard drive.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The first step would be to check the power supply (cables, outlet, power supply unit), the display, and basic components. A hard drive problem is only one of many possible causes.

fragen.frage: The 'regedit' command in Windows opens the Registry Editor, which allows you to change all system settings.
fragen.erklaerung: True! With `regedit`, administrators can make profound changes to the system configuration. However, incorrect changes can lead to serious problems.

fragen.frage: Power over Ethernet (PoE) is used to transmit only network data, but not power, over an Ethernet cable.
fragen.erklaerung: False — PoE is specifically designed to transmit both electrical power and network data over a single Ethernet cable. This simplifies the installation of devices such as IP cameras and WLAN APs.

fragen.frage: A Micro-USB connector is symmetrical and can be plugged in in both orientations.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Micro-USB connectors are asymmetrical and can only be plugged in in one orientation. USB-C connectors are symmetrical and can be used in either orientation.

fragen.frage: Social engineering is an attack that aims exclusively at the technical exploitation of software vulnerabilities.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Social engineering manipulates people to reveal information or perform actions. It is not about technical vulnerabilities, but about the human component of security.

fragen.frage: A liquid cooling processor cooler (AIO water cooling) is always louder than an air cooler.
fragen.erklaerung: False — AIO water coolers can often be quieter than air coolers at the same cooling performance, as the heat is distributed over a larger radiator and larger fans can operate at lower speeds. However, it depends heavily on the model.

fragen.frage: Verifying the hypothesis' is a step in the troubleshooting process that occurs after implementing the solution.
fragen.erklaerung: False — The hypothesis is tested before implementing the solution to determine if it is correct. After implementing the solution, 'verifying the solution' takes place.

fragen.frage: Windows updates should always be installed as soon as they become available to ensure security.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Updates often contain important security fixes and performance improvements. However, in corporate environments, a staggered rollout is common to avoid compatibility issues.

fragen.frage: A router divides a network into multiple collision domains.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A router divides a network into multiple broadcast domains. Switches divide a network into collision domains.

fragen.frage: A 'Factory Reset' of a mobile device only deletes the installed apps, personal data remains.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A factory reset deletes all user data, all installed apps, and all settings to restore the device to its factory state.

fragen.frage: The 'ping -a' command in Windows attempts to resolve the hostname from an IP address.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-a' (Resolve addresses to hostnames) option is useful for improving the readability of ping output, especially when troubleshooting DNS problems.

fragen.frage: A KVM switch (Keyboard, Video, Mouse) allows controlling multiple computers with a single set of keyboard, monitor, and mouse.
fragen.erklaerung: True! KVM switches are very useful in server rooms or for users who need to use multiple PCs simultaneously to save space and increase efficiency.

fragen.frage: The 'netstat -p' command in Linux displays the process name associated with a network connection.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The '-p' (or `--program`) option is very useful for identifying which process is responsible for which network connection, which helps in troubleshooting and security analysis.

fragen.frage: A 'Man-in-the-Middle' attack aims to completely shut down a server.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attack aims to intercept, eavesdrop on, and possibly manipulate communication between two parties without the parties noticing.

fragen.frage: A Category 6 (Cat 6) twisted-pair cable is suitable for speeds of up to 10 Gbit/s over a maximum length of 100 meters.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Cat 6 supports 10 Gbit/s only over shorter distances (up to approx. 55 meters, depending on the environment). For 10 Gbit/s over 100 meters, Cat 6a is required. Over 100 meters, fiber optic cables are necessary.

fragen.frage: A faulty network cable can cause intermittent connection problems.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A damaged or poorly laid cable can lead to packet loss, slow connection, or intermittent disconnections, which makes troubleshooting difficult.

fragen.frage: Disk Management in Windows can be used to create, delete, and format partitions.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a graphical tool for managing hard disks and partitions, which also allows the initialization of new disks.

fragen.frage: The SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol) protocol is mainly used for secure data encryption in the network.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SNMP is used to monitor and manage network devices. The older versions (SNMPv1, v2c) are insecure and transmit data unencrypted. SNMPv3 offers authentication and encryption, but that is not the primary purpose of the protocol.

fragen.frage: A 'Wireless Charger' for mobile devices uses electromagnetic induction to charge the battery wirelessly.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is the technology behind Qi and other wireless charging standards. It requires the device to be placed on the charging mat.

fragen.frage: A 'Strong Password Policy' should require a password change at least annually.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Recent findings show that mandatory, frequent password changes often lead to weaker passwords (users only change minimal parts). Instead, longer, complex, and unique passwords, multi-factor authentication, and monitoring of credential leaks are recommended.

fragen.frage: The TPM (Trusted Platform Module) technology on a motherboard is primarily used to increase CPU performance.
fragen.erklaerung: False — TPM is a security chip that stores cryptographic keys and measurements for system integrity. It is important for features like BitLocker encryption and Secure Boot, but not for CPU performance.

fragen.frage: The 'dxdiag' command in Windows can be used to diagnose problems with DirectX and display adapters.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'dxdiag' (DirectX Diagnostic Tool) displays detailed information about the system, the graphics card, and sound devices, and can help troubleshoot multimedia or graphics problems.

fragen.frage: The Windows operating system is an open-source operating system.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Windows is a proprietary operating system from Microsoft, whose source code is not publicly available. Linux is an example of an open-source operating system.

fragen.frage: A DNS server (Domain Name System) is responsible for assigning IP addresses to clients.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A DNS server resolves domain names (e.g., google.com) to IP addresses. Assigning IP addresses to clients is the job of a DHCP server.

fragen.frage: A broken home button on an iPhone is always caused by a software error.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A broken home button is physical damage and therefore a hardware problem caused by physical stress or a fall.

fragen.frage: A 'Zero Trust' security model is based on the principle of automatically trusting no one, either inside or outside the network.
fragen.erklaerung: True! It requires strict verification of every access request, regardless of where it comes from. This is a modern approach to increasing security, especially in complex and cloud environments.

fragen.frage: A SATA power cable directly supplies power to a graphics card.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SATA (Serial ATA) power cables supply power to hard drives, SSDs, and optical drives. Graphics cards are powered by PCIe power cables (6-pin or 8-pin) from the power supply.

fragen.frage: A 'Restore Point' in Windows is a full backup of the entire system, including all user data.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A restore point saves system files, installed programs, and registry settings. User data is not included. Separate backups are needed for that.

fragen.frage: The 'tracert' command in Windows displays the path that IP packets take to a destination on the network.
fragen.erklaerung: True! 'tracert' (Traceroute) is a useful network diagnostic tool to identify problems with reachability or delays along a network path.

fragen.frage: Pairing Bluetooth devices is only required once and never needs to be repeated.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Pairing must be done upon initial connection or after resetting the devices. Sometimes it may also be necessary to re-pair after firmware updates or in case of problems.

fragen.frage: Social engineering is a random attack that requires no preparation.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Successful social engineering attacks often require careful preparation, research on the target, and the development of a plausible story (pretext) to manipulate the victims.

fragen.frage: The 'Small Form Factor' (SFF) is a standard for particularly large cases that offer a lot of expansion space.
fragen.erklaerung: False — SFF (Small Form Factor) refers to computers and cases that are particularly small and compact, often for HTPCs (Home Theater PCs) or space-saving workstations. They offer limited expansion space.

fragen.frage: The 'gpresult /r' command in Windows displays the Group Policies applied to the current user and computer.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a very useful tool for administrators to check which Group Policies are applied and to diagnose problems with policy inheritance.

fragen.frage: A MAC address filter in a Wi-Fi router provides very strong protection against unauthorized access.
fragen.erklaerung: False — MAC address filters provide only very little protection because MAC addresses can be relatively easily spoofed. They are not a substitute for strong encryption (WPA2/WPA3) and passwords.

fragen.frage: The 'Safe Mode' of an Android smartphone starts the device with all third-party apps disabled.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a helpful feature for troubleshooting to check if problems (e.g., crashes, poor performance) are caused by an installed app.

fragen.frage: An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) actively blocks known malware signatures.
fragen.erklaerung: False — An IDS (Intrusion Detection System) detects and reports threats, but does not actively block them. Blocking is the job of an IPS (Intrusion Prevention System).

fragen.frage: The 'thermal paste' between the CPU and the cooler is necessary to improve the electrical connection.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Thermal paste improves the *thermal* connection by filling air gaps between the CPU heat spreader and the cooler base, which would hinder heat transfer. It does not serve for electrical connection.

fragen.frage: A 'Ghost Image' is an incremental backup of the operating system that contains only the changes since the last backup.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A Ghost Image is a full backup of a hard drive or partition at a specific point in time. Incremental backups only save changes.

fragen.frage: The HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure) protocol uses TLS/SSL to encrypt web communication.
fragen.erklaerung: True! HTTPS protects the data transmission between browser and web server from eavesdropping and manipulation, which is essential for sensitive data (e.g., logins, payments).

fragen.frage: A 'bootloader' on a mobile device is a software that downloads the operating system from the cloud.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A bootloader is a small software that runs when the device starts up and is responsible for loading and starting the actual operating system into memory. It does not download the OS from the cloud.

fragen.frage: The 'Social Engineering' technique 'Baiting' lures victims with an enticing offer that contains malware.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This can be in the form of manipulated USB sticks with enticing labels such as 'Confidential Salary Data'.

fragen.frage: A 'RAM disk' is a virtual drive that uses a portion of the main memory as fast storage.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Since RAM is much faster than SSDs or HDDs, a RAM disk can significantly improve the performance of applications that access storage intensively, but it loses its data on reboot.

fragen.frage: The 'regsvr32' command in Windows is used to open the Registry Editor.
fragen.erklaerung: False — 'regsvr32' is used to register or unregister DLL and ActiveX controls in the Windows system. `regedit` opens the Registry Editor.

fragen.frage: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) can be established over a Wi-Fi connection.
fragen.erklaerung: True! A VPN is a logical connection that can be established over any type of internet connection (Wi-Fi, LAN, cellular) to create a secure tunnel.

fragen.frage: The 'Safe Mode' on a mobile device is only for diagnosing hardware problems.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Safe Mode is primarily for diagnosing and fixing software problems caused by third-party apps or system errors.

fragen.frage: A 'Social Engineering' attack can be completely prevented by using state-of-the-art firewalls.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Firewalls protect against technical attacks on the network. Social engineering targets the human factor and cannot be prevented by technical security measures alone. Awareness is crucial here.

fragen.frage: A 'POST code' (Power-On Self-Test) on the motherboard is only visible when the computer boots correctly.
fragen.erklaerung: False — POST codes are displayed precisely when problems occur during the boot process. They help to identify the source of the error (CPU, RAM, graphics card, etc.) even before the operating system is loaded. Many motherboards have an LED display for these codes.

fragen.frage: The 'Event Log' in Windows is an important tool for troubleshooting system problems and security incidents.
fragen.erklaerung: True! The Event Viewer logs all important system events, errors, and warnings and provides valuable clues to the cause of problems.

fragen.frage: The 'taskkill /IM notepad.exe' command terminates all instances of the 'notepad.exe' process in Windows.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is useful for terminating unresponsive applications from the command line. The '/IM' option stands for 'Image Name'.

fragen.frage: The 'Internet of Things' (IoT) refers exclusively to internet-enabled household appliances.
fragen.erklaerung: False — IoT encompasses a wide range of physical objects equipped with sensors, software, and other technologies to connect and exchange data with other devices and systems over the internet. This also includes industrial plants, wearables, medical devices, etc.

fragen.frage: The Picture-in-Picture (PiP) feature on tablets and smartphones allows two applications to be displayed simultaneously in full size.
fragen.erklaerung: False — PiP allows a video or an app to be displayed in a small, floating window while using another app in full size. It is not intended for two full-screen apps.

fragen.frage: A 'spear phishing' attack is a form of general mass phishing.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Spear phishing is a highly targeted phishing attack on a specific person or organization, often with personalized information obtained from the attacker's research. It is the opposite of mass phishing.

fragen.frage: The 'cold cathode fluorescent lamp' (CCFL) is the most common backlight technology for modern LCD monitors.
fragen.erklaerung: False — CCFL was an older technology. Modern LCD monitors almost exclusively use LED backlighting, which is more energy-efficient and offers better image quality.

fragen.frage: A 'ping sweep' is a method to identify active hosts in a network segment.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This involves sending a series of ping requests to various IP addresses within a range to see which hosts respond. This is a fundamental tool for network discovery.

fragen.frage: A Type 1 hypervisor (bare-metal) is installed directly on the hardware.
fragen.erklaerung: True! Examples include VMware ESXi or Microsoft Hyper-V (when installed directly on the server). They offer the best performance as there is no host operating system in between. Type 2 hypervisors run on a host OS.

fragen.frage: A Wi-Fi repeater amplifies the existing Wi-Fi signal without affecting the bandwidth.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A repeater can extend the range, but it must receive the signal and then retransmit it, which can often lead to a halving of the effective bandwidth. A mesh system is more efficient.

fragen.frage: The 'ifconfig' command in Linux is the most modern tool for network configuration.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Although 'ifconfig' still exists, the more modern and powerful tool for network configuration in most current Linux distributions is the 'ip' command from the 'iproute2' package.

fragen.frage: An Android smartphone that won't turn on is always a software problem.
fragen.erklaerung: False — This can be a software problem (e.g., after a faulty update), but also a hardware problem (e.g., defective battery, defective motherboard, defective power button). A diagnosis is required.

fragen.frage: The 'netstat -tulpen' command in Linux shows all TCP and UDP connections and the associated processes.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This is a very powerful network diagnostic command that provides detailed information about running network services and their connections.

fragen.frage: A monitor that does not display color is always a sign of a defective graphics chip.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A monitor that does not display color (black and white image) can have many causes: a misconfigured color profile, a defective cable, a problem with the monitor itself, or a driver problem. A defective graphics chip is only one possibility.

fragen.frage: The 'systemctl restart apache2' command in Linux restarts the Apache web server service.
fragen.erklaerung: True! This command is used to restart the web server, which is often necessary after making configuration changes or to fix problems.

fragen.frage: A 'Smart Display' (e.g., Google Nest Hub) is primarily a device for displaying static images.
fragen.erklaerung: False — A Smart Display combines a screen with a voice assistant and can play videos, display recipes, control smart home devices, make video calls, and much more. It is an interactive device.

fragen.frage: Secure file encryption is the only method to protect data from any unauthorized access.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Secure file encryption is crucial, but comprehensive protection also requires physical security, strong authentication, access controls, firewalls, antimalware, and regular backups. Encryption alone is not enough.

fragen.frage: A USB 2.0 port is backward compatible with USB 3.0 devices, but only achieves USB 2.0 speed.
fragen.erklaerung: True! USB is generally very backward compatible. A USB 3.0 device can be operated on a USB 2.0 port, but at the slower speed of the USB 2.0 standard.

fragen.frage: When troubleshooting, one should assume that the user is always telling the full truth about the problem.
fragen.erklaerung: False — Users often cannot accurately describe the problem, forget important details, or even unintentionally provide false information. It is important to remain objective, ask questions, and verify the statements.
